story.storybody:
While Siddharth Sharma's family can take some consolation in the fact that the alleged killer of their son would be treated not as a juvenile but an adult, the latter's kin is all set to challenge the decision.

Rajiv Mohan, counsel for the accused, said that they would file an appeal and in this case the appellate authority would be the Children's court where the case has now been transferred.

Initially, a case under IPC Sections 304A (causing death by rash or negligent act) was lodged against the teenager but later the accused was booked for the alleged offence of culpable homicide not amounting to murder and sent to a reform home.

ACT OF NEGLIGENCE

The police had filed the final report for alleged offences under IPC Sections 304 (culpable homicide not amounting to murder), 279 (driving on a public way rashly or negligently as to endanger human life) and 337 (causing hurt by an act which endangers human life) against the juvenile accused.

Rajiv Mohan had argued that the present case was not made out under section 304 IPC (culpable homicide not amounting to murder) and the investigating officer had no justification to replace it against Section 304 A (causing death by rash or negligent act) as there is no special circumstance that exist in this case to indicate that while driving the car the juvenile had knowledge that he could cause death of the victim.

"Even after assuming but not admitting that the case is covered under Section 304 of the IPC, the same does not fall under the definition of the heinous offence provided under Section 2(33) of the Act. There is no minimum punishment prescribed under Section 304 of the IPC due to which it is not covered under the definition of heinous offences under the Act," he said.
